If this page is more than a month old when you arrive here, please check the [[QA/Test_Days|current schedule]] and see if a similar but more recent Test Day is planned or has already happened.}}<br /> <br /> == What to test? ==<br /> <br /> Today's installment of Fedora Test Day will focus on testing '''Cockpit'''. Cockpit is a server admin interface.<br /> <br /> http://cockpit-project.org<br /> <br /> == Who's available ==<br /> <br /> The following cast of characters will be available testing, workarounds, bug fixes, and general discussion ...<br /> * Development - [[User:Stefw|Stef Walter]] (stefw), [[User:Mvo|Marius Vollmer]] (mvollmer), [[User:Andreasn|Andreas Nilsson]] (andreasn), Dominik Perpeet (dperpeet), Peter Volpe (pvolpe)<br /> * Quality Assurance - [[User:jscotka|Jan \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdotka]] (jscotka)<br /> <br /> == Prerequisite for Test Day == <br /> <br /> A machine that can run Fedora 22 and that you can screw around with. This can be a virtual machine, but we are also very interested in test results on real hardware.<br /> <br /> The test machine should ideally have multiple disks and multiple network interfaces.  If you use a virtual machine, just add some virtual disks and network adapters.<br /> <br /> * '''Install Fedora 22 Server.''' Make sure that your installation is recent enough.  Either install [https://getfedora.org/en/server/prerelease/ Fedora 21 Server Alpha] or run &lt;code&gt;yum update&lt;/code&gt; in an older Fedora 22 Server installation.  You should have at least Cockpit 0.44. In the Server variant of Fedora 22, Cockpit is enabled by default.  For other variants, please refer to the Notes at the end of this page.<br /> * '''Image for virt-manager''' : http://fedorapeople.org/groups/qa/xxxxx TODO<br /> ** user/password: test/test root/internal<br /> &lt;pre&gt;<br /> # curl https://fedorapeople.org/groups/qa/xxxxx &gt; xxxx-VM-disk-image.qcow2.xz<br /> # unxz xxxx-VM-disk-image.qcow2.xz<br /> # yum -y install qemu\\*<br /> # systemctl  restart libvirtd<br /> # virt-install --connect qemu:///system --ram 1024 -n cockpit --os-type=linux --os-variant=fedora20 --disk path=xxxx-VM-disk-image.qcow2,device=disk,format=qcow2 --vcpus=1 --vnc --noautoconsole --import<br /> # virt-manager &amp;<br /> &lt;/pre&gt;<br /> <br /> Note that Docker is not enabled by default, but the test cases will tell you how to enable it.<br /> <br /> == How to test? ==<br /> <br /> After boot, Cockpit is up and running and listens on port 9090.<br /> * Point a browser at '''&lt;code&gt;http:&lt;/code&gt;&lt;code&gt;//&lt;server-ip-address&gt;:9090&lt;/code&gt;'''.<br /> * Cockpit's login page will load.<br /> * Cockpit uses a self-signed certificate, and your browser will very likely warn you about it. <br /> <br /> (Here, &lt;code&gt;&lt;server-ip-address&gt;&lt;/code&gt; is the IP address of your machine.  You can find it by logging into the machine on the text console as &quot;root&quot; and running &lt;code&gt;ip addr&lt;/code&gt;.)<br /> <br /> Once the Cockpit log in screen is loaded in your browser, log in as &quot;root&quot;.  You can log into Cockpit as any user that exists on the machine, but currently only &quot;root&quot; has enough privileges to execute the test cases. Trying with any other user, even those that are in the &quot;wheel&quot; group, will likely lead to &quot;permission denied&quot; or &quot;not authorized&quot;.<br /> <br /> The test cases are intentionally a bit vague.  They don't tell you exactly what button to click, and what to type into which field.  You have to figure that out yourself! :-) Cockpit should be `discoverable\ufffd\ufffd, and your feedback about this is very valuable.<br /> <br /> The test cases don't cover every feature of Cockpit.  Please stray from the test cases into whatever corner of Cockpit you want to explore!<br /> <br /> When Cockpit encounters an internal '''error''', a '''red &quot;Oops&quot;''' label will appear at the top right.  Please report it when this happens. Look in the javascript console (Ctrl-Shift-J) for details. It is not a good idea to continue using Cockpit after an &quot;Oops&quot;, but simply reloading the page should put you back on track.<br /> <br /> Please report your feedback either on [http://github.org/cockpit-project/cockpit/issues Github] or in [http://bugzilla.redhat.com/enter_bug.cgi?component=cockpit&amp;product=Fedora&amp;version=21 Bugzilla].<br /> <br /> == Test Cases ==<br /> <br /> * '''Basic'''<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit Login|Password change]]<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit Account|Create user account]]<br /> <br /> * '''Storage'''<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit DiskIO|Monitor disk I/O]]<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit RAID|Create a RAID Device]]<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit LVM|Create a Logical Volume]]<br /> <br /> * '''Network'''<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit NetworkIO|Monitor network I/O]]<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit VLAN|Create VLAN]]<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit Bond|Create Bond]]<br /> <br /> * '''Docker'''<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit DockerImage|Download and run image]]<br /> ** [[QA:Testcase Cockpit DockerCommit|Create a new image and run it]]<br /> <br /> == Test Results ==<br /> <br /> If you have problems with any of the tests, report a bug either on [http://github.org/cockpit-project/cockpit/issues Github] or in [http://bugzilla.redhat.com/enter_bug.cgi?component=cockpit&amp;product=Fedora&amp;version=22 Bugzilla].<br /> <br /> If you are unsure about exactly how to file the report or what other information to include, just ask on IRC and we will help you. Once you have completed the tests, add your results to the tables below, following the example results from the first line as a template. The first column should be your name with a link to your User page in the Wiki if you have one. For each test case, use the [[Template:result|result template]] to enter your result, as shown in the example result line.<br /> <br /> === Basic ===<br /> <br /> {|<br /> ! User<br /> ! Hardware<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_Login Password change]<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_Account Create user account]<br /> ! References<br /> |-<br /> | [[User:Stefw|Stefw]]<br /> | Lenovo laptop<br /> | {{result|pass||XXXXXXX}}&lt;ref&gt;Example entry&lt;/ref&gt;<br /> | {{result|fail||1000000}}<br /> | &lt;references/&gt;<br /> |-<br /> |}<br /> <br /> === Storage ===<br /> <br /> {|<br /> ! User<br /> ! Hardware<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_DiskIO Monitor disk I/O]<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_RAID Create a RAID Device]<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_LVM Create a Logical Volume]<br /> ! References<br /> |-<br /> | [[User:Stefw|Stef Walter]]<br /> | Lenovo Laptop<br /> | {{result|pass}}  &lt;ref&gt;Test entry&lt;/ref&gt;<br /> | {{result|pass}}<br /> | {{result|pass}}<br /> | &lt;references/&gt;<br /> |-<br /> |}<br /> <br /> <br /> === Docker ===<br /> <br /> {|<br /> ! User<br /> ! Hardware<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_DockerImage Download and run image]<br /> ! [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Testcase_Cockpit_DockerCommit Create a new image and run it]<br /> ! References<br /> |-<br /> | [[User:Stefw|Stef Walter]]<br /> | Lenovo Laptop<br /> | {{result|pass}}  <br /> | {{result|pass}}  <br /> | &lt;references/&gt;<br /> |}<br /> <br /> == Notes ==<br /> <br /> We recommend that you install Fedora 22 '''Server''' since we would like you to also test whether Cockpit really works out of the box.  Of course, if you would like to test Cockpit but would rather not go through the trouble of installing Fedora from scratch yet one more time, you can also add Cockpit to your existing Fedora system.<br /> <br /> &lt;pre&gt;<br /> # yum -y install cockpit docker-io fedora-dockerfiles wmdocker<br /> # firewall-cmd --permanent --add-service=cockpit<br /> # systemctl reload firewalld.service<br /> # systemctl start cockpit.socket<br /> # systemctl enable cockpit.socket<br /> &lt;/pre&gt;<br /> <br /> == Long comments ==<br /> &lt;references group=&quot;long&quot; /&gt;<br /> <br /> [[Category:Fedora 22 Test Days|c]]</div></summary>   <author><name>Stefw</name></author> </entry>   <entry>   <id>https://fedoraproject.org/w/index.php?title=Kernel&diff=406934&oldid=406931</id>   <title>Kernel</title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="https://fedoraproject.org/w/index.php?title=Kernel&diff=406934&oldid=406931"/>     <updated>2015-03-18T17:44:49Z</updated>      <summary type="html"><p>don&#039;t recommend the -B switch.  it creates a bunch of branch directories that nobody actually cares about.</p> <table class='diff diff-contentalign-left'>     <col class='diff-marker' />     <col class='diff-content' />     <col class='diff-marker' />     <col class='diff-content' />    <tr valign='top'>    <td colspan='2' style="background-color: white; Please note the caveats.</div></td><td class='diff-marker'>+</td><td style="background: #cfc; color:black; font-size: smaller;"><div><ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Fedora's kernels are signed during the build via the pesign client on a specific set of machines.&#160; To limit exposure of officially signed builds, only certain people can successfully submit builds that will be tagged into the various koji target tags.&#160; If you are not in this ACL then your build will start, but it will fail in the final tagging step.&#160; For more information and other instructions contact Org Admins.<br /> <br /> ''please answer following questions''<br /> <br /> ===Why do you want to work with the Fedora Project?===<br /> *Because I really like Fedora and the whole philosophy behind it. I have been using Fedora for years now and I would love to contribute to my favorite distribution.<br /> <br /> ===Do you have any past involvement with the Fedora project or any other open source project as a contributor?===<br /> *No, I do not have any such past involvement. I am a beginner to FOSS.<br /> <br /> ===Did you participate with the past GSoC programs, if so which years, which organizations?===<br /> *No, I have not participated in past GSoC programs.<br /> <br /> ===Will you continue contributing/ supporting the Fedora project after the GSoC 2015 program, if yes, which team(s), you are interested with?===<br /> *Yes, I would love to contribute to the Fedora project after the GSoC 2015 program. I see this program as a very nice introduction to the community and a gateway to be a regular contributor to the project. Since I know quite less about the structure of the Fedora teams right now, I will let time decide which team I would like to work with.<br /> <br /> ===Why should we choose you over other applicants?===<br /> *The main reason is that I am interested in contributing to the Fedora project in the long run. If this page is more than a month old when you arrive here, please check the [[QA/Test_Days|current schedule]] and see if a similar but more recent Test Day is planned or has already happened.}}<br /> <br /> == What to test? ==<br /> <br /> Today's installment of Fedora Test Day will focus on '''translations availability and accuracy in desktop applications'''<br /> <br /> == Who's available ==<br /> <br /> The following cast of characters will be available testing, workarounds, bug fixes, and general discussion ...<br /> * Development - <br /> * Quality Assurance - [[User:Aalam|Aalam]] (alam), [[User:lijli|Lijun Li]] (lijli)<br /> * Localization - Noriko, [[User:Anipeter|Ani Peter]] (apeter), [[User:swkothar|Sweta Kothari]](swkothar), [[User:mgiri|Manoj Kumar Giri]] (mgiri)<br /> <br /> == Prerequisite for Test Day == <br /> <br /> * Bare metal or virtual machine. [https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Getting_started_with_virtualization Start with Virtualization]<br /> * Usb key, a virtualized guest or a burned CD/DVD with the test image.<br /> <br /> == How to test? ==<br /> <br /> === Prepare Your System ===<br /> <br /> * Tests requiring ''physical media'' (e.g. DVD or CD images) <br /> * You may download a non-destructive Fedora 22 live image for your architecture. The specific live image for L10N tests can be found (here). Please note we are providing only x84_64 image for this testing. Tips on using a live image are available at [[FedoraLiveCD]]<br /> * Unless otherwise noted, you may use nightly Fedora 20 ''branch'' install images.  [[Releases/Branched|Review for information on downloading and installing Branched]].<br /> * If you are using a Alpha or pre-Alpha installation please keep in mind to update your system before running the tests.<br /> <br /> === How to run desktop in your language? ===<br /> <br /> After booting from '''Live''' iso: &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 1. On desktop top right corner click on &quot;'''Live System User'''&quot; &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 2. From menu, select &quot;'''Settings'''&quot; &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 3. In &quot;'''Settings'''&quot; window, select &quot;'''Region and Language'''&quot; &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 4. Then in &quot;Region and Language&quot; window, Click on &quot;'''Language'''&quot;, to add your language click ... ('''more''') sign at the bottom. &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 5. In window select your language (start type name in English), then select language name and Click '''Done'''&lt;br /&gt;<br /> 6. enable INPUT method, in &quot;Region and Language&quot; window, Click on &quot;'''Input Method'''&quot;, to add keyboard you want, click on plus ('+') and  ('''more''') sign at the bottom. &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 7. In window select your keyboard (start type name in English), then select keyboard name and Click '''Add'''&lt;br /&gt;<br /> 8. Click on 'Restart Now' bar will appear as in screen-shot &lt;br /&gt;<br /> <br /> [[File:Restart_now_1.jpg]] &lt;br /&gt;<br /> <br /> 9. click on &quot;'''Log Out'''&quot; Button to logout &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 10. On gdm screen just '''click''' on user name &quot;Live System User&quot; &lt;br /&gt;<br /> 11. It will ask you to update folder name to your language, try your choice. &lt;br /&gt;<br /> <br /> And start testing your language...<br /> <br /> ==== Nice to test ====<br /> <br /> Bugs you might hit or additional situations that are nice to test:<br /> * [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=720240 (as_IN)(gtk)(Translation) - Translation Error with &quot;????&quot; appearing]<br /> * [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=718906 (te_IN) Disk format message is out of screen during installation]<br /> * [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=706756  No translation on Login-Page of the reboot-menu]<br /> * [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=666038 (all languages) yum untranslated words ]<br /> * [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=726878 Semi-translated messages (translated strings missing)]<br /> <br /> == Test Results ==<br /> <br /> Specific L10N bugs like typos and translation mistakes should be directly reported to the local translation team mailing list or a bug report should be filed at [https://bugzilla.redhat.com/ Bugzilla] against the related language. General bugs that affect all languages like strings not marked for translation, downstream patching that breaks translations and input method issues should be filed against the related package. If you are unsure about exactly how to file the report or what other information to include, just ask on IRC and we will help you.<br /> <br /> == How to file bugs ==<br /> <br /> The following links helps you to guide to file both l10n and i18n related bugs:-<br /> <br /> * [http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/L10N#Bug_Reporting.2C_Testing.2C_and_Quality_Assurance Instructions to file l10n bugs]<br /> * [https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/I18N/Bugs/Guidelines Instructions to file i18n bugs]<br /> * [https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/FLTG/Gnome_bug_filing_instructions Instructions to file GNOME bugs]<br /> <br /> {{Admon/tip|Fill one bug report by component and issue|You should fill only one bug report by component and by issue.Be sure to link the report here quickly then, to let people re-use it.}}<br /> <br /> Translation teams are free to prioritize packages they find more important to test. We have made introduced a new test matrix from Fedora 18 l10n testing. Feel free to provide feedback/comments/suggestions to fltg mailing list.<br /> * The applications have been divided into Frequently Used Applications (FUAs) and non Frequently Used Applications (non-FUAs) for translation teams to prioritize packages for testing.<br /> * Further, both FUA and non-FUA lists are subdivided into project wise sections into Fedora applications, Gnome applications and Firefox.<br /> * The test matrix table below takes you to individual pages application-wise for testing.<br /> * Each test page contains test cases for each application where you can provide the test results for that application in a table format like earlier.<br /> * Click on the link in the second column in the below test matrix, which directs you to the test result page where you can enter your language name, code (fail/pass), bug filed and comments, if any.<br /> <br /> == Test Matrix ==<br /> <br /> <br /> {{Admon/note|Components are classified project wise|Both FUA and non-FUA will have Fedora and Gnome sections|Gnome bugs can be reported as per instructions provided [https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Test_Day:2013-10-03_Translation_%28l10n%29?rd=Test_Day:2013-09-26_Translation_%28l10n%29#How_to_file_bugs here].}}<br /> <br /> '''NOTE:-''' If you find any strings in English, kindly confirm whether its 100% translated in upstream. Link for upstream is provided along with each packages.
